instruction: How were chemometrics and machine learning techniques applied to the FTIR spectral data in order to determine biomolecular changes and separate the ET and healthy control groups?

Chemometrics and machine learning techniques were applied to the FTIR spectral data by using a SVM-DA (Support Vector Machine-Discriminant Analysis) model. This model was trained using the spectral data from 86 patients with essential thrombocythemia (ET) and 45 healthy volunteers as the control group. The model was calibrated using the spectral data from both groups and then used to predict the classification of new samples.

The FTIR-based results showed that in ET disease with JAK2 mutation, there are significant alterations in functional groups associated with lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids. The SVM-DA model achieved 100% accuracy in the calibration sets for both spectral regions (800-1800 cm-1 and 2700-3000 cm-1) and 100.0% and 96.43% accuracy in the prediction sets for these respective spectral regions.

instruction: Can the FTIR-based spectral method be considered superior to traditional methods for determining biomolecular changes and classifying essential thrombocythemia (ET) and healthy control groups?
Output: Yes, the FTIR-based spectral method can be considered superior to traditional methods for determining biomolecular changes and classifying essential thrombocythemia (ET) and healthy control groups. The study mentioned in the text used FTIR analysis on the blood serum of ET patients and healthy volunteers, and applied machine learning methods and chemometrics to analyze the spectral data. The results showed that there were significant alterations in functional groups associated with lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids in ET patients with JAK2 mutation. The SVM-DA model based on FTIR spectra achieved 100% accuracy in calibration sets and high accuracy in prediction sets. Additionally, changes in the dynamic spectra were identified as potential spectroscopy markers of ET. These findings suggest that the FTIR-based spectral method can effectively detect biomolecular changes associated with ET and accurately classify ET and healthy control groups.
